title: Jhin's Color Text.   Q&A thread.

embed.description: Khada Jhin, the Virtuoso"Art requires a certain...cruelty." Jhin is a meticulous criminal psychopath who believes murder is art. Once an Ionian prisoner, but freed by shadowy elements within Ionia's ruling council, the serial killer now works as their cabal's assassin. Using his gun as his paintbrush, Jhin creates works of artistic brutality, horrifying victims and onlookers.

body:
Hey all
Jhin's color text just went live. (see link)
Making this new thread to answer lore or story questions tomorrow. (March 15th 2016)

Hope ya'll like it.  Again sorry it took so long, It was a journey getting this one out the door.


Cheers.

WAAARGHbobo


PS-  just finishing up this round of Questions-- got to do some work.    I will check in later today (after 5pm PST).

This particular quote, from an omnipotent narrator's perspective, has always concerned me:

>... War awoke the tranquil nation’s appetite for bloodshed. ...

Essentially, Noxus invades Ionia, and demonstrates how much their peaceful ways really put them at a disadvantage. The specialist schools who practiced the martial arts certainly held their own - as highly trained specialists are wont to do - but the citizenry at large was essentially gunned down by the hundreds. It makes sense to me why the cultural shock of this might swing the Ionians to the opposite spectrum (peaceful isolationists to crusaders). It also makes sense to me, however, that this might strengthen Ionia's resolve to stay to its ways.

The martial schools already exist, they're just (seemingly) underpopulated. There would be an immense influx of people who want to protect their families, villages, and nation at large. To infer through subtext that a fundamental shift in Ionia would essentially put them closer to Noxus and Demacia strikes me as ... distasteful.

I could be misreading the whole foreshadowing, though. I've seen this line of story telling done before and it just always white washes the intricacies of being peaceful in the face of war mongers.

Why not play both angles?

As you have explained, many people, particularly those outside of specialized martial schools, and thus more susceptible to the suffering war brings, would experience a radical shift in opinion that goes against previous dogma. In the face of contrary evidence or apparent ineffectiveness, it should come as no surprise that many look for alternative philosophies, especially those that can grant a form of satisfying vengeance.

At the same time, there are those that remain steadfast in their ways, refusing to break under pressure and persevere no matter the cost. This can allow a greater conflict that is not limited to violence, the heart of Ionia's struggle is one of ideals: do the people change for their own benefit in a world that is also changing, or do they endure, displaying a remarkable strength of spirit.

Personally, the concept of a political divide between the population, without overt violence, is an interesting subject and provides avenues for character interaction that does not end with someone dead (mostly). Hence, I've always viewed Syndra and Zed as unintentional proponents of change that disgruntled members of the population choose to rally behind, while Karma, Irelia, and the Kinkou served as examples of adherents to the spirit of Ionia's ideals.

I just think it's better than _another _ world-threatening disaster/terror.
